headline: No End in Sight as Minnesotans Grapple With State Shutdown
snippet: All but services deemed essential cease amid an impasse between two sides with fundamentally different approaches to a $5 billion deficit.

headline: Complaint Seeks Punishment for Classification of Documents
snippet: A former official has filed a complaint against the National Security Agency and Justice Department seeking punishment of officials who classified a document he says contained no secrets.

headline: Sept. 2, 1945 | Japan Formally Surrenders to End World War II
snippet: On Sept. 2, 1945, Japan formally surrendered in a formal ceremony aboard the U.S.S. Missouri, ending World War II.

headline: In New Term, Supreme Court Shifts Focus to Crime and First Amendment
snippet: As the court returns to the bench on Monday, it faces a docket with fewer big civil cases and a possible challenge to the health care overhaul.

headline: Pundits Can Say, I Told You So""
snippet: They had predicted that Herman Cain's lack of experience and campaign savvy would eventually catch up with him.

headline: What Would You Put in Your Emergency 'Go-Bag'?
snippet: Student Opinion | Tell us what items you might pack in a go-bag" if you were evacuated from your home. Would your items be mostly practical

headline: Gingrich on the Culinary Trail in Iowa
snippet: Never a svelte figure, Mr. Gingrich seems to have put on weight as the campaign has entered its seventh month.

headline: Why Go to College at All?
snippet: Dale J. Stephens, the founder of UnCollege, explains why high school graduates would do well to skip the college experience.

headline: Tornadoes Hit South and Midwest
snippet: Several tornadoes, spawned by powerful storms that steamrolled across multiple states in the South and Midwest on Friday, caused critical injuries and widespread damage from Alabama to south-central Indiana.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 2, 2012
snippet: Can you estimate the number of seconds between free throws if you know that someone threw 20,371 of them in a 24-hour period?

headline: Fate of Postal Service Awaits Action in House
snippet: The House lags behind the Senate on legislation to help the debt-ridden Postal Service, which could begin closing post offices in two weeks.

headline: Wave of Gun Violence Challenges Seattle's Notion of Security
snippet: With six killings last week, the number of homicides in just five months in Seattle reached 21, as many as in all of last year.

headline: Wisconsin: Democrats Take Senate
snippet: Democrats won control of the State Senate on Monday, a minor prize after failing to recall Gov. Scott Walker last month over his attacks on government unions.

headline: Texas Courthouse Shooting Suspect Faces Death
snippet: A grand jury has amended the charges against the suspect in a fatal shooting outside a Texas courthouse to make him eligible for the death penalty.

headline: Mormon Says Romneys Are Leading Church Into Mainstream
snippet: The Mormon church is gaining widespread acceptance in part because of Mitt Romney, another prominent Mormon said on Sunday.

headline: Federal Review to Keep Mississippi Voter ID Law on Hold for Election
snippet: Mississippi's controversial new law requiring voters to show photo identification at the polls will not be in effect for the November general election while federal officials review whether the measure is discriminatory, the state said on Tuesday.

headline: Shuttle Prototype Enterprise Suffers Storm Damage
snippet: The flying machine that ushered in NASA's space shuttle program has suffered storm damage in New York City.

headline: Pentagon Counsel Speaks of Post-Qaeda Challenges
snippet: When the war against Al Qaeda winds down, the responsibility for mopping up scattered remnants of the group will likely fall to United States law enforcement and intelligence agencies.

headline: NJ Gov. Christie Blasts Fellow Republican Boehner
snippet: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, a Republican who has praised President Barack Obama's handling of Superstorm Sandy, on Wednesday blasted U.S. House Speaker John Boehner for delaying a vote for federal storm relief.

headline: Nebraska Lieutenant Governor Sheehy Resigns Over Phone Scandal
snippet: Nebraska Lieutenant Governor Rick Sheehy, the leading candidate to replace the current governor in the next election, resigned on Saturday after a newspaper investigation raised questions about improper cell phone calls made to women.

headline: British Pen Pal of NYC Fetish Cop: I'm No Cannibal
snippet: A British man who chatted online with a New York City police officer about kidnapping and cooking women says the talk was all fantasy.""

headline: Defense Secretary Hagel to Take Voluntary Sequester Pay Cut
snippet: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel will take a voluntary pay cut as a show of solidarity with Pentagon employees who will have to take unpaid time off over the coming months, a Defense Department spokesman said on Tuesday.

headline: APNewsBreak: Judge Axes Federal Suit Over Lake
snippet: A federal judge has thrown out a lawsuit filed by Los Angeles against air quality regulators who are requiring the city to do more to control dust on a lake that was siphoned dry a century ago to provide water for the booming metropolis.

headline: Llama Busts Loose in Fla., Subdued With Taser
snippet: When Scooter the llama busted out of his penned-in yard in Tallahassee, it took three county sheriff's deputies and a taser gun to get him back in again.

headline: Virus Deadly to Piglets Spreads to North Carolina's Hog Farms
snippet: A swine virus deadly to piglets has been discovered on two hog farms in North Carolina, an official in the No. 2 hog-producing U.S. state said on Tuesday.

headline: Documents: SEC Probing McAuliffe Former e-Car Firm
snippet: The electric-car company headed until last fall by Democratic Virginia gubernatorial candidate Terry McAuliffe and a sister company led by the brother of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton are under federal scrutiny over how they used a...

headline: GOP Senators Say Details Needed on Syria Strategy
snippet: Two Republican foreign policy hawks say President Barack Obama must make a strong case for attacking Bashar Assad's Syria if he wants to win congressional backing for the operation.

headline: Some Head Start Programs Close, and Others May Soon
snippet: The National Head Start Association estimates that nearly 19,000 children from low-income families have lost or are at risk of losing services in 11 states because of the government shutdown.

headline: U.S. Plans to Sweeten Its Sales Pitch to Foreign Investors
snippet: The Obama administration said it would expand efforts, including streamlining regulations, to make the nation more attractive to overseas companies.

headline: As Oil Floods Plains Towns, Crime Pours In
snippet: With the new prosperity, soaring crime rates have come to places in Montana and North Dakota, straining law enforcement resources and shattering the sense of safety.

headline: Money Market Fund Assets Rose $24.04 Billion
snippet: Total U.S. money market mutual fund assets rose $24.04 billion to $2.719 trillion for the week that ended Tuesday, according to the Investment Company Institute.

headline: U.S. Abortion Rate Hits Lowest Level Since 1973: Study
snippet: The abortion rate in the United States dipped to its lowest since 1973, coinciding with a steep decline in overall pregnancy and birth rates, a study from a nonprofit sexual health organization showed on Sunday.

headline: Jason Collins Set for Home Debut With Brooklyn
snippet: Jason Collins has been warmly received in his historic return to the NBA.

headline: New York Doormen Take Off Gloves, Rally for Raises
snippet: A sea of New York City doormen marched along one of Manhattan's wealthiest strips of luxury buildings on the Upper East Side in a rally for higher wages on Wednesday, and authorized their union to strike if their demands are not met.

headline: Senators Warn of Safety Risks at Closed Reactors
snippet: Five U.S. senators on Friday warned that federal regulators need to keep more emergency and security regulations in place at shuttered nuclear power plants that store tons of spent radioactive fuel.

headline: Del. Closes I-495 Bridge Because of Column Tilt
snippet: Delaware officials on Monday ordered the emergency closure of the Interstate 495 bridge over the Christina River in Wilmington after discovering that four support columns are tilting.

headline: Facebook Removes Hunting Photos of Texas Teen That Raised Ire
snippet: Facebook has removed some photographs of a Texas teenager posing with freshly killed animals she hunted during a recent safari in South Africa that had been criticized by users as inappropriate, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: Toxin Leaves 500,000 in Northwest Ohio Without Drinking Water
snippet: Dangerously high levels of toxins from algae on Lake Erie left 500,000 people in Toledo, Ohio, without safe drinking water on Saturday and sent many driving to other states in search of bottled water.

headline: Officials: Accused Texas Killer Targeted Others
snippet: The man charged in the deaths last year of two North Texas prosecutors had intended to kill other law enforcement officials, according to court documents filed Tuesday.

headline: University of New Mexico Apologizes on 'Sex Week'
snippet: An effort to promote sex education and raise awareness of sexual assault at the University of New Mexico backfired, forcing administrators to apologize.

headline: Factbox: Republican-Controlled Congress Would Have to Pick Its Battles
snippet: Republicans in the U.S. Congress would get a better chance to advance their agenda if they win control of the Senate on Tuesday but any majority is likely to be thin, requiring some Democratic support to avoid procedural hurdles.
